definition: variant of 小題大做|小题大做[xiao3 ti2 da4 zuo4]
small/tiny/few/young
surname Ti
topic/problem for discussion/exam question/subject/to inscribe/to mention/CL:個|个[ge4],道[dao4]
big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
see 大夫[dai4 fu5]
to do/to grow/to write or compose/to pretend/to regard as/to feel/writings or works
worker/workshop/(slang) troublesome/high-maintenance (person)

sentences.english: Don't make such a fuss,will you?
sentences.chinese: 請你不要小題大作好嗎？

sentences.english: My supervisor often likes to make mountains out of molehills.
sentences.chinese: 我的主管常常喜歡小題大作。

sentences.english: She made this big deal out of going on a business trip to San Francisco last week.
sentences.chinese: 上週去舊金山出差時，她有些小題大作。

sentences.english: As presidential cover-ups go, it may be splitting hairs.
sentences.chinese: 如果說總統是在掩蓋什麼，那可能有點小題大作了。

sentences.english: Whatta you mean, made a big deal?
President Obama dyes his hair?As presidential cover-ups go, it may be splitting hairs.
sentences.chinese: 如果說總統是在掩蓋什麼，那可能有點小題大作了。

sentences.english: Don't make much ado about nothing.
sentences.chinese: 意思是說庸人多自憂，不要小題大作。

sentences.english: Andy: Yeah, I think his boss is someone who likes to make a mountain out of a molehill.
sentences.chinese: 是啊，我想他的老闆是一個愛小題大作的人。

definition: vocal accompaniment in some traditional Chinese operas/to speak in support of/to chime in
lit. to point at the mulberry tree and curse the locust tree/fig. to scold sb indirectly/to make oblique accusations (idiom)
to watch with amusement as sb makes a fool of himself
to have a clear view of things/to adapt to circumstances
to play deaf-mute
to slander/to smear/to vilify
to force someone to do something
to exaggerate
gongs and drums overture to a Chinese opera/to create a disturbance
righteous indignation fills one's breast (idiom); to feel indignant at injustice
to gesticulate while talking (idiom)/to explain by waving one's hands/to criticize or give orders summarily
unexpected misfortune/unexpected accident/sudden death
to beat sb at their own game (idiom)
to reveal the cloven foot (idiom); to unmask one's true nature/to give the game away
to look for trouble
to ask for trouble/to invite difficulties
